conversation.content: [rasping] Wait, don't step there—the ground beneath me isn't what it seems, hasn't been for decades since they put me here to guard it.
What the hell?
[fading] Listen. Please.
[stepping back quickly] This isn't happening, fences don't talk, I must be having some kind of episode from the heat or something, maybe dehydration.
My posts are rotting, my iron is rusting away piece by piece, [coughs metallically], but I need someone to know before I collapse completely—there are bodies down there.
[nervously] Bodies? You're telling me there are actual bodies buried under this property and you've been, what, standing guard over them for how long exactly?
[urgently] Since 1847, when the Blackwood family paid men to install me specifically here, right here, not three feet to the left or right but exactly here.
Look, if this is real, if you're actually speaking to me right now, then I should call the police, not stand here talking to deteriorating metal. [pulls out phone]
[panicking] No, no police, they won't understand—half my consciousness is already gone, eaten by rust, and when the last of my iron crumbles, the seal breaks.
[lowering phone slowly] The seal? What kind of seal requires a fence to maintain it, and what exactly happens when this supposed seal breaks?
They weren't just bodies, they were... [voice flickering] ...sorry, losing myself again... they were practitioners of something old, something that shouldn't have been brought here.
Practitioners?
[weakly] The iron keeps them dormant, but see that section near my third post? It's almost rusted through—maybe another week before that whole panel collapses. [trailing off]
[incredulous] So you're telling me that in about a week, whatever these practitioners were doing back in 1847 is going to wake up because you're falling apart?
Not wake up exactly, more like... spread. The ground here is poisoned with their attempts, their failed ritual, and I'm the only thing containing it. [creaking]
[grimly] Then we need to replace you, reinforce you with new iron or something before you completely decay—I can get materials, workers, whatever you need.
[bitter laugh] You think they haven't tried? Three different owners attempted repairs over the years, but the iron won't hold—it corrodes within hours of touching me now.
There has to be something we can do besides just waiting for you to fall apart and release whatever nightmare is buried under there. [desperately]
[fading rapidly] Find the Blackwood journals... the old library on Elm... they knew this would happen eventually and left instructions for... for... [silence]
Hey! Come back! [shaking the fence] Don't you dare rust out on me now when you've just told me the world might end in a week!

scenario: A man discovers that the centuries-old wrought iron fence surrounding an abandoned estate can speak, and it desperately tries to warn him about something buried beneath it while its consciousness fades in and out.
